IRS990.ActivityOrMissionDescription: Village Theatres mission is to be a regionally recognized and nationally influential center of excellence in family theatre; to promote a season of top quality productions; to commission and produce new musicals that achieve national exposure; to develop a broad based appreciation for live theatre; to train young people in theatre skills for career opportunities and enriched lives; and to promote positive values through art. Significant activates are: Mainstage which produces 4 musicals and 1 nonmuscial show each season that are geared toward the entire family; Village Originals - a nationally recognized program that develops new musicals; KIDSTAGE - an uniquely designed educational program that uses theatre to build critical life skills in each participant; and Pied Piper which brings the wonderful world of live theatre to children and their families in the greater Puget Sound area by hosting renowned theatre, dance, and music companies for public and school performances.
IRS990.MissionDescription: Village Theatres mission is to be a regionally recognized and nationally influential center of excellence in family theatre; to promote a season of top quality productions; to commission and produce new musicals that achieve national exposure; to develop a broad based appreciation for live theatre; to train young people in theatre skills for career opportunities and enriched lives; and to promote positive values through art.
IRS990.Description: Mainstage productions focus on excellence in family theatre, developing a broad base appreciation for live theatre and promoting positive values through art. A Mainstage season of 4 musicals and 1 play are produced from September to August at two venues in Issaquah and Everett, Washington. Attendance was 130,647 patrons at 359 performances.

Activity2.Description: Pied Piper Presents brings live theatre to young children and school groups, which fosters an appreciation for the arts, promotes family theatre and provides educational opportunities. Pied Piper Presents brings the best of touring theatre shows for children to 3 venues in Everett, Bellevue and Mt. Vernon, Washington. Shows are selected based on educational focus and suitability to foster appreciation for live theatre in children. An audience of 25,928 attended 37 performances, including many that were offered to school groups. 4,685 students attended inschool workshops that were presented to help enhance the student's experience prior to attending the performance at the theatre.

Activity3.Description: During 2009, the Theatre continued a capital and endowment fund campaign. The campaign proceeds are being used to purchase land and build new scene, prop and paint shops (Technical Studios), reconstruct First Stage Theatre, convert an Everett City building into a theatre and educational facility, provide financial stability by establishing an endowment, retire the current mortgage, and cover the cost of the campaign. The campaign goal as of August 31, 2010 is $12.4 million. As of August 31, 2010 $6.2 miilion had been pledged or given towards the goal.

ActivityOther.Description: Theater Programs, General/Other: Village Originals is a mission driven program to commission and produce new musicals that achieve national exposure. Through the Village Originals program new works are produced to various degrees in collaboration with the show's creators. This process helps to foster the growth of new musicals in America and around the world. 1,754 people attended the Fesitval of New Musicals that was held in Issaquah which features readings and discussion of 6 new musicals. Village Theatre is one of only a handful of professional theatre companies throughout the country that commissions and develops new musicals and its reputation is continuing to grow on a national level.

Theater Programs, General/Other: The Everett Performing Arts Center is a separate live theatre facility located in Everett, WA. In addition to our Mainstage productions Village Theatre facilitates a variety of on-stage experiences to Everett audiences, including local chorale groups and children's plays. Over 78,000 patrons attended events during the year. Expenses include direct expenses associated only with outside arts programming and do not include expenses for Village Theatre programs which are required under the management contract with the City of Everett and which are included elsewhere in program service accomplishments.

Children's Theatre Program: KIDSTAGE trains young people in theatre skills for career opportunties and enriched lives by offereing classes and performance opportunties. KIDSTAGE education programs consist of year-round classes and performance opportunties in 2 locations: Issaquah and Everett. Enrollment in classes was 2,274 students. KIDSTAGE produced 8 musicals throughout the year between both locations. An audience of 11,783 attended 47 performances. Some of the performance opportunties are provided at no cost to the students, while others are tuition based.

IRS990ScheduleA.GeneralExplanation: Insurance proceeds received due to frozen pipes and broken sprinklers that caused water damage at First Stage Theatre.

Form990ScheduleCPartIV.Explanation: $6000 in support given to Artsfund in support of the Prosperity Partnership proposal to create a cultural funding district in Washington State. Some funds given to the Prosperity Partnership will be used to hire a public relations firm to create messaging and outreach strategy and hire lobbyists to lead in educating legislators in Olympia. $1250 in support given to Washington State Arts Alliance, a 501(c)(4) membership organization, that is the leading statewide arts advocacy organization working to promote public funding, legislation, and policy favorable to the arts. Village Theatre participates in Arts Day at the State Capitol in Olympia each year. A staff person is sent to represent Village Theatre at a cost of approximatly $300. The purpose of Arts Day is to provide one day that arts groups have a chance to meet with legislators and talk about arts issues in the current legislative session and cultural issues in our communities and schools.

Form990ScheduleDPartXIV.Explanation: The endowment fund is part of the current capital campaign and it's purpose is to help provide financial stability for the organization. As of 8/31/10 $8536 had been pledged or received towards a $3 million dollar goal.
Per Part VIII Form 990: Rental Expenses $40,119; Cost of Goods Sold $33,109; Fundraising Expenses $80,162
Per Part VIII Form 990: Rental Expense $40,119; Cost of Goods Sold $33,109; Fundraising Expenses $80,162

Form990ScheduleLPartIV.Relationship: A principal of the company is related to a board member
Form990ScheduleLPartIV.DescriptionOfTransaction: Foushee is the general contractor for the reconstruction of First State Theatre

OtherNonCashContributionsTable.Description: Timeshare Ownership in Whistler, BC, Canada

GeneralExplanation.ReturnReference: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, Line 11
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: At the November board meeting the Board assigns responsibility for formal review of the 990 to the finance committee and authorizes the executive committee to approve the return for filing. They also authorize the Executive Producer to sign the return. The formal review is scheduled for the January finance committee meeting. Any board members who are not members of the finance committee who are interested in formally reviewing the return are invited to attend the January finance committee meeting. Prior to the January finance committee meeting management emails the completed return to the all voting board members. Any feed back or comments are discussed at the formal review with the finance committee. At the January finance committee meeting the return is reviewed, discussed and approved by the committee. The Treasurer leads the review process and the preparer, a licensed CPA, is on hand to answer questions At the January executive committee meeting the finance committee recommends approval by the executive committee who is authorized to act on behalf of the full board. After approval by the executive committee, management electronically files the return with the IRS.

GeneralExplanation.ReturnReference: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, Line 12c
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: Annually the Board is given a copy of the conflict of interest policy and then asked to sign a certificate of acknowledgment that affirms that they have read and understand the policy and have agreed to comply with the articles of the policy. Additionally the Board annually fills out a Board questionnaire that inquires about any family or business relationships that may be potential conflicts as well as inquiring about business transactions and compensation.

GeneralExplanation.ReturnReference: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, Line 15
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: For the year ending 8/31/10, the Executive Committee of the Board of Directors of Village Theatre estabilished an Executive Compensation and Performance Review Committee. This committee met twice with the Executive Producer and reviewed goals and performance. The committee evaluated CEO salaries at comparable theatres in the National Alliance for Musical Theatre salary review and selected 990 tax returns for regional theatres in Seattle and around the country. The committee brought their compensation recommendation to the Executive Committee. The CEO compensation package was voted on by the full Board. Other key employees salaries were presented to the finance committee for review as part of the annual budgeting process which is approved by the full Board.

GeneralExplanation.ReturnReference: Form 990, Part VI, Section C, Line 19
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The organization makes governing documents, conflict of interest policy and financial statements available to the public upon request. Each year the organization produces an annual report that provides summary financial information. This document is also mailed to certain donors and is available to the public upon request.
